title-group.article-title: Do Lenders Still Monitor When They Can Securitize Loans?

abstract.p: We examine how securitization markets affect the role of banks as monitors in corporate lending. We find that banks active in securitization impose looser covenants on borrowers at origination. After origination, these borrowers take on substantially more risk than do borrowers of non-securitization-active banks. We use borrowers' geographic locations to instrument for borrower-lender matching to distinguish the effect of securitization on the banks' ex post monitoring from its effect on ex ante screening. We further investigate direct evidence of banks' monitoring role by examining their actions following covenant violations and find that securitization-active lenders are more likely to grant waivers without changing loan terms. Our results suggest that banks exert less effort on ex post monitoring when they can securitize loans.

p.mixed-citation: This practice reflects CLO managers' intentions to generate high returns by turning lower-rated collateral assets into highly rated securities. Benmelech and Dlugosz (2009) and Griffin and Tang (2012) document this alchemy of credit ratings in detail.
We use the link file provided by Michael Roberts for the matching. The details of the matching process are in Chava and Roberts (2008). We thank Michael Roberts for sharing the matching file.

The ABS database is collected and managed by Asset-Backed Alert. It contains the initial terms and origination information (including underwriting banks) for all rated CDO issues globally. We thank Asset-Backed Alert for providing this data. See Shivdasani and Wang (2011) for further discussion of this database and the list of major CDO underwriters.

If multiple lead arrangers are involved, we require all lead arrangers to be securitization active. In our sample, 43.6% of the loans have multiple lead arrangers. Our results are robust to the alternative classification that only requires at least one of the lead arrangers to be securitization active.

Additionally, our classification of a securitization-active bank varies from year to year for a given bank. This time-varying classification also helps alleviate the concern that our Securitization active dummy might capture time-invariant bank characteristics.

DealScan records loan terms at the tranche (facility) level rather than at the loan (package) level. Because we are most interested in Term Loan B, we report terms of this tranche in each loan (package). When the Term Loan B tranche is missing in the data, we take the characteristics of other term loan tranches (e.g., Term Loan C, D, and so on). To confirm whether Term Loan B is representative of all of the institutional tranches, we randomly draw 300 deals from our sample and manually check the characteristics of the institutional tranches for each deal. We find that in over 95% of all cases, all of the institutional tranches in the same deal share common features, including maturity, the presence of financial covenants, and primary loan purposes.
We thank Justin Murfin for generously providing us with his programming codes for calculating the strictness measure.

The mean covenant strictness in Murfin's sample is 22.51%. The higher probability of covenant violations in our sample reflects the fact that our sample consists of only borrowers with non-investment-grade ratings, whereas Murfin's sample includes investment-grade firms.

We recognize that loan covenants are jointly set with prices. The looser covenants we observe, however, are not likely a result of the trade-off between covenant strictness and loan spreads. Nadauld and Weisbach (2012) find that securitization leads to lower loan spreads in a similar sample of loans. Based on this finding, the trade-off theory would predict stricter covenants for securitization-inclined loans, but we find the opposite.

The KMV mcxiel backs out asset volatility from equity volatility in an option theory framework. The KMV model is widely used in empirical research of both corporate finance and asset pricing literature, including Vassalou and Xing (2004), Bharath and Shumway (2008), and Drucker and Puri (2009), among others.
Specifications analogous to Columns 1 and 2 over the 24- and 36-month windows show a similar pattern in the DTD change. In the interest of space, we do not tabulate these results.

For example, the change in DTD over the one-year window (i.e., the change in DTD from one year before loan origination to one year after) has a correlation of 0.01 (with a p-value of 0.71) with the logarithm of the total assets.

Although ROA is significant in these regressions, its level is the same in the two groups of borrowers (shown in Table 1 Panel B). Therefore, the effect of ROA on DTD changes should not bias our results.

In our sample, the median year in which a bank initially converts to securitization active is 2004. A majority of the banks retain their securitization-active status after their initial conversion. Only two banks, ABN Amro and Credit Suisse, became inactive briefly after their initial conversions.

We include both revolving loans and term loans when identifying borrower-lender relationships. When multiple lead banks are present, we treat the borrower as a repeat borrower if any of the lead banks lends to the borrower before the bank becomes active in securitization.
Ackerberg and Botticini (2002) similarly use geographic dummies for tenants' locations as instruments to resolve the endogenous matching between landlords and tenants in agricultural contracts.

One may argue that a firm can still borrow from securitization-active banks across regions without relocating its headquarters. This argument, however, only weakens the predictability of our instruments on loan securitization (i.e., the inclusion criteria) but does not affect the exclusion criteria of our instruments.

Even though Securitization active is a dichotomous variable, we estimate the first-stage regression by using an OLS to avoid the inconsistency of estimates from a probit or logit model. See Angrist and Krueger (2001) and Bennedsen et al. (2007) for more details.

In the interest of space, we only report the first-stage regression corresponding to Column 1 in Panel B of Table 6. All other specifications generate almost identical interpretations and are omitted.

We do not include lead-arranger fixed effects as in Table 2, because they drive out most variations of the dependent variable in the first stage of the 2SLS (i.e., the Securitization active dummy). Instead, we control for bank characteristics. We get similar results without controlling for these characteristics.

The Securitization active dummy is not significant in these regressions, suggesting that it captures the effect of securitization that is unique to the sample of leveraged loans. In addition, the Market CDO is not significant in this table. This reassures us that although the expansion of the CDO market coincides with the economic boom preceding the financial crisis of 2008-2009, Market CDO does not capture just the overall corporate risk taking or the trend of covenant strictness during this boom.

We thank Amir Sufi for providing the data for the research community. Details on the data can be found in Roberts and Sufi (2009a). To extend the sample period of his data, we write a script to search all 10-K and 10-Q files during 2008 to 2010 for firms in our sample using the key words listed in Roberts and Sufi (2009a). This search yields 22,480 hits, many of which are not associated with a real covenant violation. We then read the text up to ten lines before and after all the hits to identify an actual violation.
We also delete loans that are labeled as Debt-in-Possession or whose borrowers have filed for Chapter 11 or Chapter 7, because restructuring may already have been in process for these firms.

We do not include the interaction of Securitization active dummy with B-rated dummy because of a small sample size. In our regression sample, 27 loans are from securitization-active banks, seven of which are from the BB- rated group. In this case, the interaction term compares the likelihood of a waiver among the seven BB-rated firms to that of the 20 B-rated firms. Therefore, drawing any statistically meaningful inferences is difficult.

We fit the conditional logit model by keeping only the largest lead arranger if multiple lead arrangers are present in a loan. We lose twenty observations because the Securitization active dummy has no variation over time for these lead arrangers.

We collect information on the duration of waivers from borrowers' SEC filings. We read 10-Q and 10-K filings for up to eight quarters following violations that were waived by lenders. We consider that a waiver is effective until the quarter in which the borrower's financial ratios are in compliance with all covenants; this quarter then marks the end of the waiver. In three cases, we still cannot verify such compliance by the end of the eighth quarter following violation and therefore treat the eighth quarter as the end of the waiver.
We thank Shulan Fang for generously sharing her data with us.
